metadata.title: Impact of Covid -19 Pandemic on Orthopaedics at Northwell Health, New York Commentary COVID-19 and Orthopaedics: Recovery after the Pandemic Surge 1

abstract.text: The Novel Coronavirus pandemicplaced an immense strain on healthcare 3 systems and orthopedic surgeons across the world. To limit the spread, federal and state 4 governments mandated the cancellation of all non-urgent surgical cases to address surging 5 hospital admissions and manage workforce and resource reallocation. During the pandemic 6 surge, thousands of surgical cancellations have been required. We outline our experience through 7 the onset and advance of the surge, detail our incident response, and discuss the transition toward 8 recovery.
College COVID Response Team projection models estimated that without containment 18 interventions the United States could see a peak death toll of 2.2 million people by September 19 2020 2 .

In the United States, on a regional or Statewide basis, drastic restrictions to mitigate the 21 spread of the virus have been implemented, with over 90% of Americans affected by a stay-at-22 home order. Policies have limited travel, mandated social distancing and protective masks, and 23 closed non-essential businesses. Healthcare institutions have likewise taken measures in 24 anticipation of a surge of infected patients 3 .
Initially, testing was sorely limited, and false-negative controls plagued testing efforts 6 .

Gradually, new technologies improved testing sensitivity, specificity and availability 7 . This 67 allowed us to successfully test almost all patients and at-risk healthcare workers, inspiring 68 confidence in our staff and bolstering effective patient care. 69 70 Elective Surgical Case Cancellation 71 During the onset, Northwell Health mandated the cancellation of all non-urgent surgical 72 cases to address surging admissions and workforce and resource reallocation. Only emergent 73 orthopaedic cases continued 8 . Operative patients were directly admitted to the hospital, avoiding 74 187 prioritization guidelines, operating room (OR) block time distribution, preferential use of ASC's, 188 and preoperative protocols. 189 Staff Reintegration 190 As the demand for OR time escalates, so will the need for OR and perioperative staff to 191 return from redeployment in COVID positive units. Repatriation of perioperative and OR staff 192 will allow for restoration of orthopaedic OR and post-anesthesia teams. To avoid deleterious 193 effects on patient care, the transition must be step-wise, using teamwork and extensive 194 communication among all healthcare professionals 22 . Once front line subspecialties no longer 195

need extra assistance, and removing staff will not disrupt patient care, redeployed personnel will 196 be reintegrated back to their primary position. Before restarting, employees will be given the 197 9 opportunity to voluntarily obtain antibody testing. Employees with high-risk exposure to 198 COVID-19 will be allowed two-weeks to quarantine, and repeat testing before returning. Once 199 capacity, workforce, and safety issues have been addressed, elective procedures can begin. 200 Approach to Operative Case Priority 201 Redistribution of OR availability, a precious commodity, must be handled in an ethical, 202 judicious, and patient-centric manner. Over 16,000 postponed surgical cases, including 1,800 203 orthopedic, need to be performed at our institution. The Surgical Emergency Operations 204 Committee (SEOC) will use clinical guidelines and a multidisciplinary approach to prioritization, 205 fostering transparent, equitable, and ethical decisions 8,23 . Cases will be classified into priority 206 levels using time-sensitive criteria corresponding to their likelihood of harm due to delays in 207 surgery as outlined in Figure 1. It is the surgeons' responsibility to initially identify the Level 4 208 (Emergent) and Level 3 (Urgent) priority cases that have been postponed. They will submit case 209 information via the system database to the Department Chair of each service for approval prior to 210 scheduling (Figure 2). The SEOC will provide oversight of all scheduled cases. Once approved, 211 department administrators will contact the surgeon to provide booking information. After the 212 case is booked, pre-surgical and COVID-19 PCR testing will be the responsibility of the 213 attending surgeon and team. Cases without a resulted COVID-19 PCR test will be cancelled to 214 ensure the safety of all involved (Figure 2). In regard to Level 2 (semi-urgent) and Level 1 (non-215 urgent), as well as, elective orthopedic surgery cases, a phased in approach is anticipated and 216 being prepared for based upon New York State regulatory approval. The beginning of elective 217 surgical cases is predicated in our state by reduced disease burden and hospital capacity outlined 218 by the phase three criteria provided by the White House 16 . 219 Novel Adaptations 220 10

The potential implementation of 7-day a week elective surgery scheduling will allow for 221 improved volume, but workforce issues will need to be addressed. This workflow initiative is 222 being modeled with hiring new OR staff; staggering existing OR team shifts, promoting positive 223 leadership, adding necessary resources, and employee incentives 24 . Consideration will be given 224 to directing outpatient procedures to ASCs, while directing hospital procedures to those requiring 225 admission for >23 hours, further maximizing non-COVID-19 patient safety, hospital bed, and 226 operating room availability 8,25 . Additional initiatives have begun to expand traditional ASC 227 block schedules to incorporate limited stay cases adopting "23-hour" post-recovery schedules. 228 229 Patient Experience 230 231 While this pandemic has had a significant effect on the hospital system, we must be 232 cognizant of the impact on patients. With high, pandemic related unemployment, some patients 233 may struggle to afford surgery 26,27 . During the 2008 global recession, financially motivated 234 cancellations of elective orthopaedic cases increased as the economic situation worsened, 235 correlating positively with unemployment rate and negatively with job availability 27 . In addition, 236 economic downturns negatively affect health metrics: physician visits, diagnostic rates, surgical 237 procedures, and disease incidence 28,29 . Surgical postponement can have deleterious effects on 238 patient mental and physical well-being. Health initiatives must focus on supportive patient 239 communication. Regaining patient confidence in the fact that seeking elective healthcare is safe, 240 as well as accurately informing patients of risks, including COVID-19 transmission risks, could 241 begin in the outpatient setting. Providers must understand that patient may have concerns about 242 undergoing surgery at this time, or about their potential exposure to COVID-19 in doing so. 243 Regardless of the risks, patients must be well informed; a trusting physician-patient relationship 244 is instrumental in providing quality care and fostering patient satisfaction. Northwell Health has 245

body_text.text: In New York (NY) State, the first confirmed COVID-19 case was on March 1st, 2020, 26 and exponential spread of the virus across the NY City metropolitan area resulted in a global 27 epicenter. The first COVID-19 patient was admitted to a Northwell Health hospital on March 4 th , 28 2020. The Northwell Health System is the largest healthcare system in NY State with 23 total 29 hospitals, 5,692 beds, 18 office sites, and 14 ambulatory surgery center (ASC) sites carrying out 30 over 33,000 orthopedic surgical cases yearly. A surge of infected patients followed, culminating 31 in a peak of cases requiring admissions and complex resuscitative treatment. Our purpose is to describe our experience through the onset and advance of the surge, 39 detail our incident response, and discuss the transition toward recovery. As the largest healthcare provider in the state, Northwell Health was on the frontlines 44 during the response to the outbreak. Emergency Departments (ED) first witnessed the 45 devastating consequences as the proportion of daily hospital admissions from the ED exploded 46 from 20% to over 45% at the peak in early April. More than 6,000 patients with suspected 47 COVID-19 were admitted across the health system, with 28% requiring ICU admissions and 48 25% requiring mechanical ventilators. Our Emergency Operations Center saw the early need for personnel and resource reallocation at the 5 tertiary and 11 community hospitals in which 50 orthopedic surgery is performed in our health system. By early April, institutional hospital 51 capacity increased by 23%, effectively creating 1,200 additional beds above the pre-existing 52 capacity of 5,200. To "load balance" the patient surge across the system, ICU patients were 53 transferred from overcrowded smaller hospitals to larger tertiary centers. The ramifications of this pandemic and the anticipated radical changes that it may have 253 on our healthcare system and society are still not fully understood. The future remains unclear, 254 but clearly the scope of our practice has been dramatically altered 30,31 . Orthopaedic surgery and 255 healthcare in general will rapidly evolve and changes will be incorporated into our standards of 256 care. Evidence-based protocols and innovative technology enables efficient identification of risk, 257 resource utilization, and minimization of exposure 31 .

The challenges we face are shared among the orthopaedic community and should serve to 259 galvanize our efforts. As we progress through this ordeal, preparations must be made to safely Pending cases submitted to system database Department Chair and Admin Director confirm priority level
The Department Chairs will approve cases to fill allocated service time slots

The Surgical Emergency Operations Committee leadership reviews all data Patient medical clearance performed at ambulatory office; surgeon's office confirms time with patient COVID testing 24 to 48 hours prior to the scheduled surgery date, results sent to OR leadership Medical clearance is the responsibility of the attending physician COVID positive cases will be cancelled unless they are Level 4 (emergent) priority The Endoscopy unit operates as a non-COVID facility and does not currently treat COVID positive patients All patients are screened for COVID-19 prior to entry into the preoperative areas and tested before admission or any procedure.
Ample personal protective equipment is available for both patients and healthcare workers

FIGREF0.text: Crisis management teams assembled to prepare for reorganization of hospital and33 ambulatory operations including a large-scale contraction of orthopedic operations. This resulted 34 in reduction of ambulatory patient visits and postponement of thousands of surgeries. Efforts to 35 expand the COVID-19 treatment teams additionally prompted the redeployment of 14% of 36 orthopedic attending faculty staff, 40% of residents and fellows, and 82% of Advanced Clinical 37 Practitioners (ACPs) including physician assistants and nurse practitioners.

FIGREF3.text: the healthcare team was pivotal in the face of unclear viral transmission, 59 disease expression, and serologic immunity phenomena. Important infection mitigation strategies 60 were adequately supplying, and conserving limited supplies of personal protective equipment 61 (PPE) as well as providing exposure training to providers and patients. PPE distribution was 62 prioritized to the front-line providers and testing centers 4,5 .

FIGREF4.text: the ED. Encouragement of timely surgery, and fast-tracking of medical clearances, 75 radiologic studies, and physical therapy, minimized inpatient overnight stays and helped expedite 76 discharges. Our healthcare system performed approximately 2,970 emergent surgeries during a 77 4-week period at our 16 orthopedic hospital sites, efficiently utilizing limited hospital resources 78 while providing imperative patient care. 79 Emergent orthopaedic surgical cases continued to be performed based upon clinical 80 criteria including acute fractures, dislocations, tendon and ligament ruptures, and any cases in 81 which a delay would likely result in an adverse result 8 (Figure 1). Postponed cases (orthopaedic 82 and non-orthopaedic) were tracked and entered into a database using the American College of 83 Surgeons case acuity triage guidelines 9 . Non-surgical treatments for certain conditions were 84 carefully adopted in selected cases as long as the timing of the procedure would not affect 85 clinical outcome. Finally, the process for rescheduling of these postponed cases is expanded 86 below.

FIGREF5.text: above, 14% of orthopedic attending faculty staff, 40% of residents and fellows, and 91 82% of Advanced Clinical Practitioners (ACPs) including physician assistants and nurse 92 practitioners were redeployed to COVID-19 treatment teams to manage both the surge of 93 COVID-19 patients and as other providers were quarantined for potential viral exposure or 94 became ill with COVID-19. An "All Hands On Deck" attitude prevailed. 95 To alleviate ED workloads, a Musculoskeletal (MSK) Fast-Track was created, 96 streamlining all MSK patients to orthopedic providers for evaluation while avoiding the ED as 97 possible. However, with stay-at-home orders in place, a decline in acute traumatic injuries led to 98 diminished need for orthopedic care.

FIGREF6.text: to the virulence of the virus, as well as the uncertainty resulting from this 102 new pathogen, healthcare workers were at risk of contracting the virus and transmitting the virus 103 to their patients and/or families. At-risk healthcare workers require clear communication, 104 emotional support, and effective leadership. Despite resilience, uncertainty, fear, and loss have 105 been physically and psychologically exhausting. Social and familial disruption, unfamiliar 106 settings, exhausting shift work, and a near 88% death rate in ventilated patients 10 have affected 107 the healthcare team's mental health. Evidence from this pandemic and prior crisis has 108 demonstrated the importance of maintaining healthcare worker wellness 8,11 . Along with 109 mitigation strategies, Northwell Health has comprehensively supported our healthcare workers 110 by providing educational classes, mental health resources, and grief counseling. Protecting the 111 health of our front-line providers has been a foremost concern.

FIGREF7.text: use of telehealth services allows us to provide healthcare while minimizing the risk 116 of disease transmission 12,13 . Telehealth capabilities were already integrated into certain 117 specialties prior to the pandemic, most notably behavioral health services in the ED. The rapid 118 adoption and expansion of telehealth services by our orthopaedic department was key in 119 engaging actively symptomatic and postoperative patients, and instrumental in maintaining 120 continuity of care.

FIGREF8.text: allowed our program to continue the scheduled curriculum. Virtual 125 platforms have become common in residency training during the pandemic 14 , facilitating remote 126 sharing of educational resources among orthopedic residents and attending faculty. Cancellation 127 of elective surgeries, inter-hospital residency rotations, and in-person skills labs may have 128 repercussions on resident training and surgical proficiency. While the ACGME has suspended 129 minimum case requirements for competency 15 , our residency programs are exploring innovative 130 ways to practice surgical skills with weekly training modules, online webinars, and remote 131 access virtual reality proficiency-based training.

FIGREF9.text: April, the White House released guidelines on a step-wise approach to reopening the 137 country 16 . Regions need to document downward trends in suspected and confirmed COVID-19 138 cases over a 14-day period, safely restore non-crisis inpatient and critical care bed capacities, and 139 provide a testing program for repatriated healthcare staff. Regions that satisfy this gating criteria 140 may enter into phase one, allowing for elective outpatient surgery to be reinstated at COVID-141 contained facilities. States not demonstrating rebound infections, while meeting the gating 142 criteria after implementation of phase one, may progress into phase two and resume elective 143 surgeries on an outpatient and inpatient basis. States with no evidence of rebound infections, 144 while continuing to meet the gating criteria after implementing phase two, may progress to phase 145 three. This lifts visitation restrictions on hospitals and senior care facilities 16 .

FIGREF10.text: Provider Safety Restoration of elective orthopedic procedures requires downward trends in active cases, 150 widespread disease and serologic testing, and effective contact tracing. Performing elective 151 procedures without creating a safe hospital environment can have adverse effects on outcomes 152 and may lead to resurgence. Elective orthopedic surgery patients treated while the patient was in 153 the incubation period of COVID-19 infection resulted in a 44.1% rate of ICU admission 154 postoperatively, with a mortality rate of 20.5% 17 . Poor surgical outcomes in undiagnosed 155 patients, along with a 25-50% transmission rate from asymptomatic carriers, necessitates testing 156 in order to limit the potential spread of disease burden 18 157 Initiation of preoperative testing protocols can be an effective screening method for protecting 158 against exposure and resurgence 19 . Patients log their daily temperatures leading up to surgical 159 admission and are screened for any symptoms on arrival. All patients should be tested 24-48 160 hours prior to their procedure, with repeat testing if the clinician has high index of suspicion in 161 the presence of a negative test result. Additionally, patients who develop new symptoms 162 consistent with a newly acquired infection or worsening symptoms after previously testing 163 negative or inconclusive for COVID must be tested again. Finally, those patients previously 164 testing positive must successfully complete a two-week quarantine period and then be retested 165 before their surgery.

FIGREF11.text: the safety of our patients, clinicians, and team members is our utmost 168 priority, and we have implemented many processes to ensure this. This includes the creation of169 dedicated segregated OR's, PACU's, and inpatient units for all levels of care for non-COVID 170 surgery. To maintain a safe environment within the hospital, Northwell Health has begun surface 171 and air SARS-CoV-2 contamination sampling. A quantitative viral 'heat' map is generated, directing decontamination and safety protocols in high viral-load areas. Furthermore, Northwell 173 Health will reopen and staff dedicated COVID-19-contained ASC's and inpatient hospitals for 174 elective procedures. 175Wearable sensor technology can track trends in resting heart rate and daily activity to 176 identify seasonal respiratory illnesses 20 , and may serve to detect and contain outbreaks.

FIGREF12.text: Additionally, contact tracing has been a pillar of disease control in public health 21 , and 178 implementation of exposure alert systems are being facilitated by partnerships between the CDC 179 and software companies. As we reinstate elective surgery, these tracing methods foster a safe 180 environment by monitoring active cases.181 182Restarting the OR-Logistical Challenges183 184As healthcare institutions more effectively manage SARS-CoV-2, consideration must be 185 given to the logistics of reinstituting elective orthopaedic procedures. Multiple factors need to be 186 addressed including staff reintegration and workflow, elective surgical rescheduling and recommended key talking points to surgeons to share with their patients, this is outlined in Continued use of telemedicine may minimize patient exposure during physical therapy 247 and rehabilitation, and may be used pre-and postoperatively 12 . Implementation of digital 248 technology will support clinical care including patient rehabilitation during the recovery phase.

FIGREF13.text: 260 transition our healthcare system from disaster operations back to conventional patient care. The 261 SARS-CoV-2 pandemic is a test of global cooperation; only through dissemination of knowledge 262can we overcome this existential threat.

FIGREF15.text: Classification of Priority Level When Considering Operative Procedures After Restarting Elective Surgery. Level 4: Emergent •Delay would cause immediate severe harm or death •Delay would result in permanent disability or severe harm •Patient is medically unstable related to a surgical Level 3: Urgent •Delay would prolong current hospital stay or increase the likelihood of later hospital admission during the pandemic •Patients have failed medical management of a surgical condition Level 2: Semi-Urgent •Delay or further delay beyond 3 months risks patient harm •Delay would increase the risk of a hospital stay or create the likelihood of later hospital admission Level 1: Non-Urgent •Delay or further delay beyond 6 months poses minor or no risks of patient harm Level 0: Elective •Timing of procedure does not affect clinical outcome Process for Operating Room (OR) Case Scheduling for Identified Postponed Cases

FIGREF16.text: Talking Points to Highlight Safety Measures and Inspire Patient ConfidenceSegregated operating rooms, recovery units, and inpatient units have been created to exclusively treat non-COVID positive patients
